block.p: U.S. and Britain Agree To Aid U.N. in Sierra Leone The United States and Britain will help bail out a United Nations peacekeeping mission in Sierra Leone that appears to be overwhelmed, with rebels killing civilians in the capital, Freetown, and holding more than 500 peacekeepers hostage. Britain will send about 700 troops to secure the airport, so that Europeans can leave. The Clinton administration agreed to provide transport planes.

Britain will send about 700 troops to secure the airport, so that Europeans can leave. The Clinton administration agreed to provide transport planes.
At least four people were killed when rebel groups clashed outside the home of the main rebel leader, Foday Sankoh, and thousands of protesters marched on his compound.
Pulling Back in Congo Uganda and Rwanda agreed to pull their troops from Kisangani, Congo's third largest city, and to let United Nations forces control the area.
Sri Lanka Rebels Reject Deal The government rejected an offer from Tamil rebels of a cease-fire in exchange for the government's promise to withdraw thousands of troops from a peninsula.

Speeding Lebanon Pullout Plan Israel, after a spate of border violence last week, is speeding up preparations to withdraw troops from southern Lebanon in case Prime Minister Ehud Barak decides to do so before his deadline of July 7.

U.S. Aid Effort Criticized An internal State Department report says the Clinton administration has done a poor job of delivering emergency aid to the people who need it. It says the officials responsible for relieving human suffering in foreign crises have little influence over high-level decision-making, and in some cases are shut out.
Kosovo Albanian Is Killed A well-known commander of the disbanded Kosovo Liberation Army, Ekrem Rexha, was shot dead outside his home in Prizren.

Book Protest in Cairo The police fired rubber bullets and tear gas at a demonstration by up to 2,000 students Al Azhar University who were protesting a novel, ''Banquet of Seaweed,'' which they said insults Islam.
Germany Honors Soldier Germany renamed a base in Rendsburg after a soldier in Hitler's army who disobeyed orders, saved hundreds of Jews and was executed by the Nazis for his acts.

Clinton Plan for Forests Would Limit Road Building A draft proposal by the Clinton administration to safeguard national forests from development would bar road building across nearly one-quarter of those lands but would not immediately rule out future logging or off-road vehicle activity. People active on both sides of the issue said they hoped it would be revised.

Los Angeles Police Inquiry Police and city officials agreed with the nation's top civil rights enforcement officer, Bill Lann Lee, the acting assistant attorney general for civil rights, to begin negotiations about long-sought changes in police training and procedures in an effort to avert a federal lawsuit.

Gore Pushes China Trade Bill Vice President Al Gore spoke more forcefully that he customarily has for permanent normalized trade relations for China, which Congress is to vote on this month. Mr. Gore has been tepid in backing the agreement, largely because organized labor, which backs him, opposes it.

G.O.P. Primary Rivals to Meet Gov. George W. Bush and Senator John McCain, left, are to meet in Pittsburgh today, their first face-to-face encounter since Mr. Bush's victories in the Super Tuesday primaries.

Clinton's Side in License Case President Clinton told a disciplinary panel of the Arkansas Supreme Court that despite a federal judge's finding that he was in contempt of court in the Monica Lewinsky case, he had not technically lied before the judge, and he urged the panel not to take away his law license, according to papers filed by opponents. He also cited his years of public service in arguing that no penalty harsher than a reprimand should be imposed.

Outlawing Bias Based on Size The San Francisco Board of Supervisors passed an ordinance that makes it illegal to discriminate against people based on their size, by adding height and weight to the same antidiscrimination codes that provide protections for people based on race, religion, color, ancestry, age, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, disability and place of birth.

Controlled Fire Is Not A fire set by the National Park Service to clear an overgrown area in New Mexico has blown out of control, forcing the evacuation of thousands of people and threatening the Los Alamos National Laboratory.
Cardinal Is Laid to Rest After Solemn Ritual Cardinal John O'Connor was entombed beneath the altar of St. Patrick's after a televised funeral Mass that was attended by 3,500 people.

Parental Anger at Arrests The police arrested about a third of 1,000 demonstrators pressing for legalization of marijuana on Saturday, and some of the protesters' parents expressed anger at the length and conditions of the detentions.
Backing for Rises in Rent The city's Rent Guidelines Board gave preliminary approval to raising one-year leases by 4 percent and two-year leases by 6 percent for rent-stabilized apartments.

Gas Detector Was Inoperative The police in Nassau County, on Long Island, said a doctor who came home to find six relatives and friends dead of carbon monoxide poisoning recalled disconnecting a carbon monoxide detector last summer.
Devils Go to Eastern Finals The Devils beat the Toronto Maple Leafs, 3-0, to win their second-round N.H.L. playoff series.

The Art of Speculation An item offered on eBay as a ''great big wild abstract art painting'' was bid up to $135,805 on speculation that it might be a 1952 work by Richard Diebenkorn, who died in 1993.
Tony Award Nominations ''Kiss Me, Kate'' led with 12, including best musical revival.

Tracing the Jewish Diaspora Biologists using a new technique based on the male chromosome traced the diaspora of Jewish populations from the dispersals that began in 586 B.C. to modern communities in Europe and the Mideast.
New Light on Down Syndrome Scientists have essentially completed the DNA sequence of chromosome 21, a result that sheds light on the workings of Down syndrome.

Suspects in Virus Attack Philippine officials, accompanied by F.B.I. agents, raided an apartment in Manila that they suspect was the launching pad for a malicious computer program that disrupted computer systems around the world last week. A man was taken into custody; his roommate, a woman whom officials spoke with by phone, agreed to turn herself in. Officials said there might be more suspects.
Ad Agency Acquisition Young & Rubicam ended 77 years of independence by agreeing to a $5.7 billion takeover by the WPP Group, a rival based in London. It is the largest deal in industry history.

3Com to Distribute Palm Stock 3Com said it would distribute its shares of Palm to its own shareholders in late July, setting the stage for the closing of the stock price gap that has existed ever since Palm went public in early March. Since then, Palm has traded at prices that appeared to be unreasonably high relative to the price of 3Com shares.

Technology Shares Suffer The Nasdaq dropped 147.44 points, or 3.9 percent, to 3,669.38, pulled down by Cisco, after an article in Barron's questioned its market capitalization. The Dow rose 25.77 points, to 10,603.63, but the S.& P. 500 dropped 8.46 points, to 1,424.17.
Editorials: President Vladimir Putin; New York's message on clean air; watery grave for a Roman ruin. Columns: Thomas L. Friedman, Gail Collins.
